awd_titl_txt: Quantum Information Theory with Spatially Separated Parties
awd_abstract_narration:
Many of the most important phenomena in the field of quantum information involve spatially separated quantum subsystems. These subsystems may be entangled, correlated in a way that cannot be explained within classical physics. All subsystems can communicate classical information with each other (LOCC, for local operations and classical communication). Important examples of such protocols include entanglement generation and manipulation, quantum teleportation, quantum key distribution and cryptography, and certain proposed implementations of quantum computing. A formal mathematical description applicable in general to these situations is known to be rather complex and difficult. Therefore, it is an important open problem to fully understand the LOCC class of measurements, but progress along these lines has been limited up to the present time. One important step will be to understand how LOCC differs from the larger class of separable measurements. 

The Principal Investigator (PI) has recently devised a novel method of determining whether or not a separable quantum measurement can be implemented by LOCC. If it can, the approach devises an LOCC protocol which does so. If successful, the proposed work will extend this result to further understand how LOCC differs from separable measurements, and will also address important questions about LOCC itself, such as whether it is possible to bound the amount of communication needed at each round. The aim will also be to extend the PI's recent results on LOCC measurements to what is known as quantum operations, where the concern is only about the overall statistics that emerge from all the outcomes taken together. The proposed work will also contribute to our understanding about the creation of entanglement between two spatially separated systems, in part as an extension of the PI's recent results on the capacity of a bipartite unitary operation to create entanglement. 

Broader impact: The PI has long been involved in undergraduate and graduate education, and his involvement in research has improved the quality of his teaching and deepened his interactions with students, contributing to education at both undergraduate and graduate levels through the PI's supervision of undergraduates in research projects and collaboration with graduate students. The PI is a frequent seminar speaker to a quantum information seminar series at a local university. The PI has also published several pedagogical papers and is presently working on a new one on the topic of quantum teleportation.

por.por_cntn:
We have developed a new and quite general approach to the study of quantum information processing involving subsystems distributed among multiple spatially separated parties. When the parties lack the ability to bring their separate subsystems together into a single laboratory, they are restricted to measuring their individual local quantum systems and communicating outcomes of those measurements to their distant counterparts, who based upon those outcomes, choose their own local measurements to subsequently perform. This procedure is collectively known as LOCC (local operations and classical communication), within which one `round' is meant to refer to one party's measurement followed by her communication of the result to the other parties. The process of LOCC plays a critical role in many of the most important aspects of quantum information processing, examples including quantum teleportation, quantum cryptography, and certain proposed implementations of quantum computing. It is also generally accepted that LOCC is highly complex and difficult to analyze. Therefore, it is one of the most significant problems in quantum information theory to find ways of better understanding LOCC, along with ways of determining what can, and cannot, be accomplished by LOCC.


Studies of LOCC have most commonly involved looking at specific, individual physical tasks, such as the determination of which quantum state a system was prepared in---known as quantum state discrimination---or the transformation of a quantum system from one state to another. In contrast, our approach addresses questions about LOCC in ways that apply to all physical tasks in general. These ideas have led to a better understanding of how to determine when a general quantum process can be implemented exactly by LOCC, including two distinct methods for designing specific protocols for their implementation. They also provide ways of determining when quantum processes can be closely approximated by LOCC, a question that is intimately related to considerations of what becomes possible as one allows more and more rounds of communication.


Specific results include the discovery of a geometric condition on measurements that when violated, implies that no finite-round LOCC protocol exists. We then found an infinite class of example measurements for which that condition is violated, proving that none of these examples can be implemented by finite-round LOCC. Using a different condition, which we also discovered and which is necessary for LOCC as well, we showed that the set of finite-round LOCC measurements is intimately intertwined with the set of measurements that can be implemented by LOCC but only by using an infinite number of rounds. One consequence of the latter result is that there exist measurements that require an infinite number of rounds, but which can be closely approximated with no rounds, that is, without using any communication at all. We have also found a method of designing LOCC protocols, which starts at the end of the protocol and works backward toward the beginning. We later discovered a new method for designing LOCC protocols which starts at the beginning and works, round by round, toward the end. The advantage of this latter method is that a failure to find a protocol implies that the given measurement cannot be implemented by LOCC even if an infinite number of rounds of communication are allowed, a conclusion that cannot be reached when using the earlier method. We have also recently extended this latter approach to the study of quantum channels, which may be thought of as measurements made by an environment, but where the environment is never observed so that the outcome of the measurement remains unknown.
